name: IFN-MI_HRR-Vis-VUV-HHG
institution: CNR - Istituto di Fotonica e Nanotecnologie - Milano
Applications:
UPGRADE
The high repetition rate, visible-VUV HHG spectroscopy setup is seeded by a 1030 nm, 40 kHz Yb:KGW amplified laser system. The driving source for HHG is a few-cycle Mid IR Optical Parametric Amplifier (MIR-OPA) that generates mid-infrared pulses tunable from 3 to 10 μm. The harmonics can be generated in transmission or reflection geometry and are acquired in the 1000 nm - 40 nm spectral range. The samples can be mounted on a motorized rotational stage for characterizing the harmonic response as a function of the sample orientation, and a broadband polarimeter allows the full characterization of the harmonics polarization state in the visible range. Furthermore, we can conduct time-resolved measurements (TR-HHG) by pumping the crystal under investigation with pulses at 1030 nm, 515 nm visible/NIR wavelengths and with the MIR-OPA. Measurements can be performed in the 20 - 500K temperature range.

The optical pump – THz probe beamline is equipped with an 800 nm Ti:sapphire amplified laser system, producing 50 fs laser pulses with a repetition rate of 1 kHz. THz generation occurs in a 1 mm-thick ZnTe crystal, resulting in a single-cycle THz pulse with a bandwidth between 0.25 and 2.3 THz and a peak electric field intensity of approximately 1 kV/cm. The setup offers two measurement configurations: transmission or reflection at a 45° angle of incidence. The THz beam's spot size at the sample position is 0.7 mm in diameter. The interaction chamber is continuously flushed with nitrogen gas. Measurement can be performed at RT.

name: IFN-MI_HHG
institution: CNR - Istituto di Fotonica e Nanotecnologie - Milano
Applications:
The beamline allows the investigation of the high-order harmonic generation (HHG) process in crystalline solids, allowing access to strong out-of-equilibrium properties of condensed matter by HHG spectroscopy.
The driving source for HHG is a few-cycle Optical Parametric Amplifier (OPA) that generates mid-infrared pulses tunable from 3 to 4 microns. It can deliver 200 μJ pulse energy at 3.2 μm with a duration of 100 fs. The harmonics can be generated in transmission or reflection geometry and are acquired in the spectral range 2500 – 200 nm. name: IOM_CLUSTER_MBE-oxide
institution: CNR - Istituto Officina dei Materiali -  Trieste
Applications:
The Molecular Beam Epitaxy (MBE) is a technique for the growth of epitaxial thin film. In MBE the desired elements are sublimated in special devices called evaporators (by thermal annealing) or introduced in the chamber in gas phase. In both cases the atoms stick on a substrate creating a solid solution in thin film form. The MBE can be performed only in Ultra High Vacuum (UHV) condition. The technique is characterized by a very small deposition rate (typically less than 1 nm per minute) that permit the deposition of thin film with the best possible thickness precision. Moreover, this technique give rise to thin films with high purity stoichiometry and a high control on their crystal structure.
The MBE-Oxide chamber is designed for the growth of complex oxides in pure ozone or oxygen as oxidizing ambient. The growth chamber is equipped with in-situ noninvasive measurement of atomic fluxes in real-time for single component materials (quartz crystal monitor) and for multi-component compound (atomic absorption spectroscopy). The deposition of individual monolayers is monitored by in situ reflection high energy electron diffraction (RHEED) system.
Sample: Perovskite structure compounds deposition, like doped manganites, ferroelectric and multiferroic based thin films and heterostructures.
Monitors: RHEED, LEED/Auger, transport measurements

name: IOM_CLUSTER-MOKE
institution: CNR - Istituto Officina dei Materiali -  Trieste
Manufacturer and model: Electromagnet: Kepko GMW 5403. Detector: Thorlabs PDA25K-EC; PDA100A2. Lock-in: NF LI 5640.
Applications:
MOKE apparatus is present on the MBE Cluster growth system. In this setup it is possible to perform Magneto Optic Kerr Effect (MOKE) measurements in both longitudinal and polar configurations and to record hysteresis loop measurements both in UHV and on air. 
In this system polarized light impinges on the sample located between the poles of the electromagnet. The reflected light passes through a photoelastic modulator and the analyzer optical lens, which is set close to extinction. The signal is then detected by a photodiode. The current signal finally passes through a lock-in amplifier, giving the Kerr signal of the sample. The optical components are mounted on an optical table. 
When MOKE measurements are done with the sample in air, a dedicated sampleholder allows to control the sample position and azimuthal and phi rotations, to allow for polar plots. In case of measurements in UHV, the sample is placed on the head of the UHV manipulator and the measurements take place with the laser light passing through a dedicated viewport. In this configuration the samples can be cooled down to 30 K (cooling with a He liquifier) and stabilized by feedback at any temperature between 30 K and 500 K. The azymuthal angle can be varied by 360 degrees (around an axis perpendicular to the surface) enabling the measure of in-plane magnetic anisotropy. Several setups with the poles of the electromagnet allow to modulate the magnetic field intensity up to 0.6 Tesla. Two sets of lasers and detectors allow working at 635 (red) and 405 (blue) nm wavelengths, for a laser spot on the sample of around 500 um of diameter.
The UHV setup used for MOKE measurements is a fully equipped sample preparation and surface science characterization chamber, including electron beam evaporation sources, LEED, sputter gun, an annealing stage, two gas lines.
Sample: Non-transparent samples.
Ancillary Techniques: LEED, RGA, Ar+ sputtering gun, electron beam evaporation sources; gas lines.

name: ISM-ROMA_Transient Absorption Spectrometer
institution: CNR - Istituto di Struttura della Materia - Roma
Applications: Transient Absorption Spectroscopy in the UV-Vis-NIR pump-probe wavelength range to study ultrafast processes in materials (nanostructured, plasmonic, and photovoltaic materials), as well as in molecules. In the experimental setup is available high repetition rate pump-probe spectroscopy that provides information of the time resolved dynamics at low pulse energy, meeting the linear regime of the matter and the operating conditions of the devices.
Source: Transient Absorption Spectroscopy involves the excitation of the sample using tunable light from the optical parametric amplifier (240 – 2500 nm) and probing with a time delayed white light supercontinuum (240 – 1600 nm). Both the transient absorbance and reflectance can be recorded as a function of temporal delay (maximum delay time 1 ns) of the arrival of the probe with an overall resolution of 50 fs. The source of the optical parameter amplifier is a regenerative amplifier seeded by a mode-locked Ti:Sa oscillator: pulse duration 35 fs, repetition rate 1 kHz, power 4 W@800 nm. For the high repetition rate laser source Yb-based - pulse duration 170 fs - 5 W@1031 nm - single pulse up to 1 Mhz repetition rate + Optical Parametric amplifier pulse duration 120 - 200 fs optimized at 50 kHz repetition rate.
Source Energy Range: Pump wavelength range 240-2500 nm, probe energy range 240-1600 nm, repetition rate 1 kHz.  High repetition rate pump wavelength 315-2600 nm, probe energy 500-900 nm, repetition rate 50 kHz.
Overall Spatial Resolution: Pump spot size 150 um , probe spot size 100 um
Sample: The sample can be mounted in air and in a high vacuum cryostat at LN temperature.
Environment: The samples can be measured at atmospheric pressure or at a pressure of 10E-4 mbar.

Applications: APE-HE end station for XAS/XMCD/XPS measurements is a UHV chamber equipped with a 4 axis manipulator and an hemispherical electron energy analyzer. It is built as a vibration-free sample chamber with mu-metal shielding for reducing the background H-field. The sample manipulator allows X-Y scanning on the surface with 1 micrometer precision and is therefore suitable to perform experiments on microstructures. The sample environment allows for temperature control (He-flow cryostat and heating stages) with feedback, for H-field application in the surface plan up to 0.1 T and for E-field application up to 500 V between contacted surfaces and substrate. The total electron yield (TEY) detection is achieved by measuring the drain current with a high sensitivity electrometer through highly shielded connections, or with an in vacuum electron multiplier. The total fluorescent yield (TFY) detection is achieved by an in-vacuum photodiode. Continuous scanning of the monochromator for XAS spectra is available for superior speed. Step-by-step scanning is also available and used to perform highly sensitive XMCD while switching the in-plane magnetization of the sample at each point. Two independent electrical connections on the measuring position of the sample allow applying electric bias during or in-between the measurement. The possibility of combining electric and magnetic fields allows studying the chemical and magnetic behaviour of multiferroic materials and heterostructures.

name: IOM_APE-HE
institution: CNR - Istituto Officina dei Materiali -  Trieste
Applications:
APE-HE end station for XAS/XMCD/XPS measurements is a UHV chamber equipped with a 4 axis manipulator and an hemispherical electron energy analyzer. It is built as a vibration-free sample chamber with mu-metal shielding for reducing the background H-field. The sample manipulator allows X-Y scanning on the surface with 1 micrometer precision and is therefore suitable to perform experiments on microstructures. The sample environment allows for temperature control (He-flow cryostat and heating stages) with feedback, for H-field application in the surface plan up to 0.1 T and for E-field application up to 500 V between contacted surfaces and substrate. The total electron yield (TEY) detection is achieved by measuring the drain current with a high sensitivity electrometer through highly shielded connections, or with an in vacuum electron multiplier. The total fluorescent yield (TFY) detection is achieved by an in-vacuum photodiode. Continuous scanning of the monochromator for XAS spectra is available for superior speed. Step-by-step scanning is also available and used to perform highly sensitive XMCD while switching the in-plane magnetization of the sample at each point.

Two independent electrical connections on the measuring position of the sample allow applying electric bias during or in-between the measurement. The possibility of combining electric and magnetic fields allows studying the chemical and magnetic behaviour of multiferroic materials and heterostructures.
Source: Elettra synchrotron
Environment: He-flow cryostat and heating stages, H-field application in the surface plan up to 0.1 T and for E-field application up to 500 V
